description: Word 2016 Advanced for Mac explores ways to enhance Word documents with graphical elements that include images, shapes, tables, and charts. The series also demonstrates different techniques for users to automate tasks by using templates, macros, and mail merge. While Word 2016 Advanced for Mac is a continuation from the Word 2016 Essentials for Mac series, it can be viewed as a standalone course for users looking to go beyond just adding and formatting text.

episodes.description: Word 2016 Advanced for Mac explores ways to enhance Word documents with graphical elements that include images, shapes, tables, and charts. The series also demonstrates different techniques for users to automate tasks by using templates, macros, and mail merge. While Word 2016 Advanced for Mac is a continuation from the Word 2016 Essentials for Mac series, it can be viewed as a standalone course for users looking to go beyond just adding and formatting text.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.556
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.556 --> 00:00:11.360
Hello everyone, my name is Vonne Smith and
this is Microsoft 2016 Advanced for Mac.

3
00:00:11.360 --> 00:00:12.900
In this course overview,

4
00:00:12.900 --> 00:00:17.090
we're going to be covering exactly
what is in this particular course.

5
00:00:17.090 --> 00:00:19.460
Who is the target audience,
who is this made for?

6
00:00:19.460 --> 00:00:21.880
What do we need to know about
before we get started, and

7
00:00:21.880 --> 00:00:25.380
any tip bits of information
that we have extra?

8
00:00:25.380 --> 00:00:28.110
In this course, there are two main topics.

9
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:30.960
There is the graphical elements and
automation.

10
00:00:30.960 --> 00:00:35.235
So this is where we're going to be
focusing on those elements that,

11
00:00:35.235 --> 00:00:37.860
well are graphics, things like images.

12
00:00:37.860 --> 00:00:40.980
We're gonna talk about how you can
put images into your document,

13
00:00:40.980 --> 00:00:46.470
all about the important textwrap, and
even a little bit of document and

14
00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:50.190
image resolutions and
how you should kind of be aware

15
00:00:50.190 --> 00:00:54.600
of the sizes of your images when you go
ahead and place them into your Word files.

16
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:58.300
We're also going to be getting into
shapes and how to format them,

17
00:00:58.300 --> 00:01:00.310
how to make them,
how to make them different colors,

18
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:04.380
and talk about all the fun stuff
you can do with the styles.

19
00:01:04.380 --> 00:01:06.900
We're going to talk
about SmartArt as well.

20
00:01:06.900 --> 00:01:08.765
I love me some SmartArt.

21
00:01:08.765 --> 00:01:14.045
It's a nice way to be able to display
your information in a graphical manner.

22
00:01:14.045 --> 00:01:18.960
Give a little bit more oomph to that
information within your Word documents and

23
00:01:18.960 --> 00:01:22.350
your different reports where
things like org charts and

24
00:01:22.350 --> 00:01:27.620
different ways that you want to
demonstrate cycles or diagrams.

25
00:01:27.620 --> 00:01:30.210
That would be what we have for SmartArt.

26
00:01:30.210 --> 00:01:32.310
We're also going to be
getting into tables.

27
00:01:32.310 --> 00:01:36.140
Tables is where you go ahead and organize
information into rows and columns.

28
00:01:36.140 --> 00:01:41.060
You might think, hm tables don't seem
like images and graphics, but it

29
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:45.910
is that graphical element of a different
way of representing that information.

30
00:01:45.910 --> 00:01:52.920
And how it works differently in a table
format and how that table interacts

31
00:01:52.920 --> 00:01:58.525
like a graphical element within
the rest of your document.

32
00:01:58.525 --> 00:02:01.555
We'll also be getting into charts
where we will be making some

33
00:02:01.555 --> 00:02:03.195
clustered column charts.

34
00:02:03.195 --> 00:02:05.195
We'll be making some pie charts and

35
00:02:05.195 --> 00:02:08.875
just understanding the foundations
of charts because there's a lot of

36
00:02:08.875 --> 00:02:12.385
terminology that is associated with
charts that it kind of throws people off.

37
00:02:12.385 --> 00:02:15.895
So we really kind of start at
a foundational level and then go ahead and

38
00:02:15.895 --> 00:02:19.150
insert as another graphical element.

39
00:02:19.150 --> 00:02:20.900
Let me get into automation.

40
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:26.500
These are things to help make your working
in Word faster and more efficient.

41
00:02:26.500 --> 00:02:28.918
I'm going to start with templates.

42
00:02:28.918 --> 00:02:34.280
Everybody loves templates but I feel
that people kinda use the terminology

43
00:02:34.280 --> 00:02:38.780
a little bit, well, not exactly how
you're suppose to use it in Word.

44
00:02:38.780 --> 00:02:41.430
So we clarify what
exactly is a template and

45
00:02:41.430 --> 00:02:45.350
how to correctly use a template in Word.

46
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:47.060
We also get into macros.

47
00:02:47.060 --> 00:02:49.910
How you can record your steps and
be able to play them back.

48
00:02:49.910 --> 00:02:53.786
That can really take the time that it
would do for multiple steps just kinda

49
00:02:53.786 --> 00:02:57.740
put it all into one little clickable
button and be able to run that anyways.

50
00:02:57.740 --> 00:03:00.736
But of course, there are some down sides,

51
00:03:00.736 --> 00:03:05.481
some security issues that we need
to cover within those episodes and

52
00:03:05.481 --> 00:03:11.500
we do a good job of letting you know how
to be safe with your macros in using Word.

53
00:03:11.500 --> 00:03:15.040
Get into some linked objects
about putting in some Excel

54
00:03:15.040 --> 00:03:19.400
data into your Word document, how you can
link back to that particular file, and

55
00:03:19.400 --> 00:03:21.150
all the nuances that are with that.

56
00:03:21.150 --> 00:03:24.300
And then we get into
the ever popular mail merge.

57
00:03:24.300 --> 00:03:27.260
We go into making some
different letters and

58
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:32.410
we do labels and
envelopes and lots of fun.

59
00:03:32.410 --> 00:03:34.160
So who is this for?

60
00:03:34.160 --> 00:03:40.190
All Office users with a capital O, meaning
that this is for the Office 365 users.

61
00:03:40.190 --> 00:03:44.382
It doesn't matter if you're in a physical
office or if you're at a home office or

62
00:03:44.382 --> 00:03:47.200
just, you know,
you're in your living room.

63
00:03:47.200 --> 00:03:49.690
So that's why we have
that capital O there.

64
00:03:49.690 --> 00:03:53.676
And I call this the upper
basics to advanced level.

65
00:03:53.676 --> 00:03:56.934
So this is where,
kind of going into that prerequisites,

66
00:03:56.934 --> 00:04:01.530
you're gonna need to have a little bit
of a foundational knowledge of Word.

67
00:04:01.530 --> 00:04:03.360
We have the Word Essentials series, so

68
00:04:03.360 --> 00:04:07.830
that is more like a precursor
to this particular course.

69
00:04:07.830 --> 00:04:10.230
So things like you need to know
about like what is a style.

70
00:04:10.230 --> 00:04:14.460
You need to know about page layout,
how to select text, how to format text.

71
00:04:14.460 --> 00:04:19.690
All of those kind of foundations
of Word would be very helpful for

72
00:04:19.690 --> 00:04:21.190
this particular series.

73
00:04:21.190 --> 00:04:26.150
Then you do need to know a little bit
about your Macintosh operating system,

74
00:04:26.150 --> 00:04:27.900
understanding what the Finder is.

75
00:04:27.900 --> 00:04:30.650
We do get into a little bit more
of a keyboard shortcuts in this

76
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:34.160
particular series, so
just having familiarity with that.

77
00:04:34.160 --> 00:04:37.580
And, of course,
being familiar with other Office products.

78
00:04:37.580 --> 00:04:40.390
We will be talking
a little bit about Excel.

79
00:04:40.390 --> 00:04:42.210
If you've never used Excel,

80
00:04:42.210 --> 00:04:46.610
you might wanna watch a show that we
have in our course library about that.

81
00:04:46.610 --> 00:04:51.330
But knowing one helps with other Office
products, so that's always a good thing.

82
00:04:52.500 --> 00:04:57.420
We do have exercise files and
episode notes that accompany every single

83
00:04:57.420 --> 00:05:01.190
one of these particular videos that
you're going to be watching, so

84
00:05:01.190 --> 00:05:02.860
definitely check that out.

85
00:05:02.860 --> 00:05:07.090
They should all be available to you
right here within this course overview.

86
00:05:07.090 --> 00:05:09.740
Meaning, all of the exercise files for

87
00:05:09.740 --> 00:05:14.040
every episode within this show,
so check that out.

88
00:05:14.040 --> 00:05:18.760
And if they're ever missing or if I'm
referring to a file that's not in that,

89
00:05:18.760 --> 00:05:19.910
let us know.

90
00:05:19.910 --> 00:05:23.320
We need to know and make sure that we
have all of our ducks in a row for

91
00:05:23.320 --> 00:05:27.900
you guys to be able to follow along
with me and have lots of fun.

92
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:31.210
And talking about fun,
we have some extras.

93
00:05:31.210 --> 00:05:33.910
This is always something I talk
about in all of my course overviews,

94
00:05:33.910 --> 00:05:35.730
is there's always other options.

95
00:05:35.730 --> 00:05:39.500
There's a whole bunch of
ways to do things in Word,

96
00:05:39.500 --> 00:05:43.206
so if I haven't covered all of them,
there's a lot of them.

97
00:05:43.206 --> 00:05:48.210
Updates do happen and different versions,
being that this is an Office

98
00:05:48.210 --> 00:05:53.300
365 product and is always updating,
you might be on an older version or

99
00:05:53.300 --> 00:05:56.990
a younger version than
the one that I'm using.

100
00:05:56.990 --> 00:05:58.000
So definitely check that out,

101
00:05:58.000 --> 00:06:01.610
you can always see if you need to
have updates from your Help menu.

102
00:06:01.610 --> 00:06:05.398
And you can always check out
what version of a product

103
00:06:05.398 --> 00:06:10.219
that you're using through your
account settings in the home tab or

104
00:06:10.219 --> 00:06:13.833
the backstage view when
you go into the file menu,

105
00:06:13.833 --> 00:06:19.374
you should have some options there to
show exactly what version you're on.

106
00:06:19.374 --> 00:06:23.061
Because that may make a difference as
to what you're seeing on your screen

107
00:06:23.061 --> 00:06:25.030
versus what I'm showing on my screen.

108
00:06:26.300 --> 00:06:27.930
Always searching for answers.

109
00:06:27.930 --> 00:06:30.280
The internet is a wealth
of information out there.

110
00:06:30.280 --> 00:06:34.360
I do reference a lot of the Microsoft
help files within the notes.

111
00:06:34.360 --> 00:06:35.670
That should be a good place to start.

112
00:06:35.670 --> 00:06:40.070
But do some searches on your own to
get those answers that you might need.

113
00:06:40.070 --> 00:06:42.310
Everybody uses these products differently.

114
00:06:42.310 --> 00:06:46.030
So maybe you're really interested in mail
merge, well we have some episodes on that.

115
00:06:46.030 --> 00:06:49.590
Maybe you don't really use charts but
it's always good to know

116
00:06:49.590 --> 00:06:53.820
that it's available and you never know
down the road when you might need that.

117
00:06:53.820 --> 00:06:55.020
And always have fun.

118
00:06:55.020 --> 00:06:58.460
I know it can be frustrating sometimes
when you're trying to figure out like why

119
00:06:58.460 --> 00:07:00.600
doesn't this chart wanna move around.

120
00:07:00.600 --> 00:07:02.170
Well, we got that wordwrap on it.

121
00:07:02.170 --> 00:07:05.990
But just remember to just kinda, while
we're learning, have some fun in here.

122
00:07:05.990 --> 00:07:08.280
We like to have fun and I hope you do too.

123
00:07:08.280 --> 00:07:11.039
And I will see you in
some future episodes.

124
00:07:11.039 --> 00:07:15.672
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Vonne introduce the basics concepts of working with images. They differentiate file formats and explain the importance of understanding image resolution and dimensions. Vonne also shows some basic techniques for sizing images in Preview.
episodes.title: Images: Basic

grabbed up another
document really quickly.

Vonne but you don't want to miss anything,

00:19:50.316 --> 00:19:57.354
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Cherokee explore how to format images. They show how to resize images visually with the image bounding box and manually by typing in dimensions in the ribbon. They also discuss the different types of word wrap, how to crop images, and how to reset an image's effects and size.
episodes.title: Images: Format

You have to hit the tab key or just

episodes.description: Vonne and Cherokee continue demonstrating image formatting.  In this episode, they cover image borders and effects, preset styles, color corrections, artistic effects, and remove background. They also discuss the importance  of adding alternative text to images for accessibility as well as when to compress pictures in a document.
episodes.title: Images: Format Part 2

So if it's something to be aware of,

642

658
00:33:54.800 --> 00:33:57.781

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Vonne add shapes into documents to enhance the appearance and emphasize text. Vonne shows how to add shapes and then format shapes by resizing, rotating, and changing the color of the fill and outline. She also shows how to add and format text to a shape, format shapes with the format pane, and edit individual points to create custom shape.
episodes.title: Shapes: Add and Format

So I can like, move that up a little bit.

But you can see, each one of these points,

To go ahead and just manipulate

Maybe in my prime, my word tips and tricks

[LAUGH] But just play around with it

00:33:46.449 --> 00:33:46.949

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Vonne demonstrate working with multiple shapes. With shapes, Vonne shows how to duplicate, arrange stacking order, align, group and ungroup, and use the selection pane. She also covers how to insert icons, which is only available with an Office 365 subscription.
episodes.title: Shapes: Align, Arrange and Group

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne discuss the purpose of and explain how to use SmartArt in Word. Vonne shows how to add SmartArt from the different galleries and then add shapes and text. She shows how to format individual shapes and/or the whole SmartArt using styles as well as how to resize, wrap text, and align within a document.

episodes.description: Vonne and Cherokee present the foundational knowledge and basic terminology associated with tables in Word.  They discuss the importance of understanding the different mouse cursor icons to able to select the right table element for formatting and table manipulation.  They also demonstrate how to treat a table as a graphical element in a Word document.
episodes.title: Tables: Introduction

When we had this one

And I hope that this introduction

So, I hope that's a great introduction for

00:29:50.207 --> 00:29:56.410

episodes.description: Vonne and Cherokee continue to explore tables in Word 2016 for Mac. Vonne shows how to insert rows and columns, as well as adding text into cells. The ladies discuss why one would or would not want to merge cells, split cells, or split tables. They also explain several ways to modify a table layout such as: specifying height and width, auto-fit options, distribute rows/columns, cell alignment/margins, text directions and more!
episodes.title: Tables: Create and Layout

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Vonne discuss how to convert text into table content and vice versa. Vonne shows how to create custom tables using the draw table command. Vonne also demonstrates how to calculate totals using basic formulas as well as sorting data by single and multiple levels.
episodes.title: Tables: Create and Layout Part 2

episodes.description: Vonne and Cherokee discuss how to format tables and cell content. Vonne shows how to apply borders and shading to selected cells using the Table Tools contextual tabs as well as text formatting from the Home tab on the Ribbon. They also demonstrate how to format using styles and how to clear formatting completely.
episodes.title: Tables: Format and Design

00:19:33.910 --> 00:19:36.190
Is there anything else
you'd like to show us?

366
00:19:36.190 --> 00:19:39.580
>> No, people are like, what,
you did four episodes on tables?

367
00:19:39.580 --> 00:19:40.640
I'm like yeah, we did.

368
00:19:40.640 --> 00:19:43.130
Because there is a lot to talk about.

369
00:19:43.130 --> 00:19:45.290
Because it's like just
throw it on a table.

370
00:19:45.290 --> 00:19:47.350
But we like to slow it down here.

371
00:19:47.350 --> 00:19:51.640
We like to go ahead and
explain everything, really get into it.

372
00:19:51.640 --> 00:19:55.520
And hopefully you won't fight with tables,
cuz.

373
00:19:55.520 --> 00:19:58.560
>> Also,
you can't teach an old dog new tricks.

374
00:19:58.560 --> 00:20:00.850
That's not true, but
it's just really hard.

375
00:20:00.850 --> 00:20:01.765
I'm the old dog.

376
00:20:01.765 --> 00:20:06.480
[LAUGH] And if you learn the right
way from the beginning sometimes,

377
00:20:06.480 --> 00:20:09.480
it's almost better So
you don't have to break any bad habits.

378
00:20:09.480 --> 00:20:12.100
You just create good
habits from the onset.

379
00:20:12.100 --> 00:20:16.840
>> Yeah and hopefully this will
eliminate the frustration that you

380
00:20:16.840 --> 00:20:20.210
maybe been experiencing, same way I have.

381
00:20:20.210 --> 00:20:22.290
And that's where we all come from.

382
00:20:22.290 --> 00:20:26.430
And it's just understanding all,
it's really the mouse cursor icon.

383
00:20:26.430 --> 00:20:27.460
It's so big.

384
00:20:27.460 --> 00:20:30.450
That's what trips people
up every single time.

385
00:20:30.450 --> 00:20:35.580
It's taken four episodes to go through
our different things in the tables,

386
00:20:35.580 --> 00:20:38.000
it's like a mini series [LAUGH].

387
00:20:38.000 --> 00:20:41.770
It's like a tables mini series, and
now we have come to the conclusion and

388
00:20:41.770 --> 00:20:43.740
now everybody is like.

389
00:20:43.740 --> 00:20:46.730
And that is a nice little and
all done music is going to play us off

390
00:20:46.730 --> 00:20:48.090
>> Check this off my list.

391
00:20:48.090 --> 00:20:50.605
Move on the next skill
I am going to learn.

392
00:20:50.605 --> 00:20:51.830
>> Yes.
>> Well thank for

393
00:20:51.830 --> 00:20:53.930
that Vonne that transference of knowledge.

394
00:20:53.930 --> 00:20:55.630
Thank you for being with us as well.

395
00:20:55.630 --> 00:20:58.540
But for this show we are going
to go ahead and sign out.

396
00:20:58.540 --> 00:21:00.170
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

397
00:21:00.170 --> 00:21:00.980
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

398
00:21:00.980 --> 00:21:03.523
>> See you next time at Office Pro TV.

399
00:21:03.523 --> 00:21:11.520
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Justin and Vonne introduce the foundations and terminology associated with charts.  They identify and define key terms such as data series, category axis, plot area, data labels, and many more.  They also show examples of different chart types and chart formatting options.
episodes.title: Charts: Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.719 --> 00:00:16.050
Greetings everyone and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:16.050 --> 00:00:18.304
I'm your host Justin Dennison and

4
00:00:18.304 --> 00:00:22.820
we're getting back into
Microsoft Word 2016 Advanced for Mac.

5
00:00:22.820 --> 00:00:23.331
Whoo!

6
00:00:23.331 --> 00:00:26.419
I was a little scared I wasn't
gonna make through that but I did.

7
00:00:26.419 --> 00:00:30.480
And particularly in this episode
we're gonna start with charts.

8
00:00:30.480 --> 00:00:34.210
I also didn't mean to rhyme in that so
this is gonna be an interesting show.

9
00:00:34.210 --> 00:00:38.620
Luckily we have someone just
as interesting, if not more,

10
00:00:38.620 --> 00:00:39.239
Miss Vaughn Smith.

11
00:00:39.239 --> 00:00:40.820
How you doing today, Vaughn?
>> I'm doing fantastic.

12
00:00:40.820 --> 00:00:42.866
How are you?
>> I am doing also

13
00:00:42.866 --> 00:00:43.885
well.
>> [LAUGH]

14
00:00:43.885 --> 00:00:44.694
>> I was scared there at the beginning.

15
00:00:44.694 --> 00:00:45.758
>> I was rooting for you.

16
00:00:45.758 --> 00:00:48.108
>> That's a long title and I rhymed,

17
00:00:48.108 --> 00:00:49.166
I don't know.

18
00:00:49.166 --> 00:00:50.002
It's crazy.

19
00:00:50.002 --> 00:00:54.430
But charts, in my previous experiences,
I'm like, ooh, charts are good.

20
00:00:54.430 --> 00:00:59.310
But visualization of data is, a lot of
times, more important than the actual

21
00:00:59.310 --> 00:01:01.410
data itself.
>> Excatly, and

22
00:01:01.410 --> 00:01:02.730
I loved how you introduced it.

23
00:01:02.730 --> 00:01:07.030
We are doing a graphical
representation of our information.

24
00:01:07.030 --> 00:01:09.170
And I just rhymed there too didn't I?

25
00:01:09.170 --> 00:01:10.580
Look at that.

26
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:13.880
We are starting from the very
beginning and this is an introduction

27
00:01:13.880 --> 00:01:17.490
episode to where we're just gonna
get familiar with the terminology.

28
00:01:17.490 --> 00:01:18.982
It's all about these big words.

29
00:01:18.982 --> 00:01:19.631
What's a data series?

30
00:01:19.631 --> 00:01:22.390
What's a category axis?

31
00:01:22.390 --> 00:01:26.395
So I just wanna kind of introduce
you to the topics, the words,

32
00:01:26.395 --> 00:01:32.025
show you some examples and
just get us familiar with everything so

33
00:01:32.025 --> 00:01:36.785
then we move on into actually inserting
a chart and then going into formatting it.

34
00:01:36.785 --> 00:01:39.792
I do like to kinda break these up
just like we did with the tables.

35
00:01:39.792 --> 00:01:43.078
We're just gonna go ahead and
take it chunks like that and

36
00:01:43.078 --> 00:01:45.642
make it a little bit more digestible for
us.

37
00:01:45.642 --> 00:01:49.492
So we're gonna start off with a handy,
dandy PowerPoint presentation.

38
00:01:49.492 --> 00:01:52.762
So there's nothing like presenting
information with PowerPoint.

39
00:01:52.762 --> 00:01:55.674
So why don't we go ahead and
jump on down into here.

40
00:01:55.674 --> 00:01:58.342
I'm not running the show in full screen or
anything like that.

41
00:01:58.342 --> 00:02:02.393
I just wanted to kinda, Get this here so

42
00:02:02.393 --> 00:02:07.498
I can have a little road map
as to where we're going.

43
00:02:07.498 --> 00:02:10.950
So we did talk about tables
in the previous episodes.

44
00:02:10.950 --> 00:02:12.612
And this is just an example of tables.

45
00:02:12.612 --> 00:02:14.600
And it's giving us the information.

46
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:18.570
Okay, this is the activities of
my two cats Fuego and Bishop.

47
00:02:18.570 --> 00:02:22.010
You can see how much they sleep and
eat and play and meow.

48
00:02:22.010 --> 00:02:25.393
And it's just the raw data, the numbers.

49
00:02:25.393 --> 00:02:32.860
But does this table communicate
the information as well as, maybe, this?

50
00:02:32.860 --> 00:02:33.830
Okay, wow, okay.

51
00:02:33.830 --> 00:02:35.400
This gives it a little bit more color.

52
00:02:35.400 --> 00:02:38.670
We can see, wow, who's the orange one?

53
00:02:38.670 --> 00:02:39.678
That's Bishop.

54
00:02:39.678 --> 00:02:42.960
I come over here, orange is Bishop.

55
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:46.699
And sleep, I can see it down here
at the bottom that is the activity.

56
00:02:46.699 --> 00:02:47.732
I have some nice labels.

57
00:02:47.732 --> 00:02:50.520
I say, okay, this is the hours in the day.

58
00:02:50.520 --> 00:02:53.750
And yeap,
that column right there is the highest.

59
00:02:53.750 --> 00:02:59.060
So we can see, that yeah, sleeping takes
the cake with the activities of a cat,

60
00:02:59.060 --> 00:03:02.020
which is usually true, at least for mine.

61
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:08.856
So this is going to be that graphical
representation of our data and we're gonna

62
00:03:08.856 --> 00:03:14.181
learn how to be able to actually create
this type of clustered column chart.

63
00:03:14.181 --> 00:03:17.620
Right there, getting in that
terminology of what is this?

64
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:21.730
I'm sure we've all probably seen
these before in presentations.

65
00:03:21.730 --> 00:03:24.030
But did you know it was
a clustered column?

66
00:03:24.030 --> 00:03:29.638
Did you know that across the bottom
this is known as the category axis?

67
00:03:29.638 --> 00:03:32.163
If you really think about it, it's like,

68
00:03:32.163 --> 00:03:35.320
alright if we're looking
at the activities of a cat,

69
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:39.758
well what categories of activities do
we have and what are we comparing?

70
00:03:39.758 --> 00:03:43.986
We're comparing Fuego and
Bishop to each other but

71
00:03:43.986 --> 00:03:48.418
we're also comparing across
all of our categories.

72
00:03:48.418 --> 00:03:51.254
So again those words that Microsoft, and

73
00:03:51.254 --> 00:03:57.005
really just charts in general I would say,
use to say, hey, those orange columns,

74
00:03:57.005 --> 00:04:01.642
that's known as a data series and
the bottoms are your activities.

75
00:04:01.642 --> 00:04:05.602
And the value axis, that's the one
that's going up the vertical and so

76
00:04:05.602 --> 00:04:07.230
these are your hours.

77
00:04:07.230 --> 00:04:10.392
And then what is orange and what is blue?

78
00:04:10.392 --> 00:04:12.270
Well then that's the legend.

79
00:04:12.270 --> 00:04:18.537
That's going to give you the labels that
are associated with those data series.

80
00:04:18.537 --> 00:04:22.643
The other thing to notice in this
particular slide is notice that right here

81
00:04:22.643 --> 00:04:26.680
there's this little, well,
it's really just the table.

82
00:04:26.680 --> 00:04:32.350
Coming back over to here,
this is the data for this chart.

83
00:04:32.350 --> 00:04:38.570
So where this is coming from is going
to be in something known as the chart

84
00:04:38.570 --> 00:04:44.020
in Microsoft, well this says PowerPoint
but it's gonna be Word when we use Word.

85
00:04:44.020 --> 00:04:47.278
So it's using Excel but not really Excel.

86
00:04:47.278 --> 00:04:51.301
It's this weird, Mid level.

87
00:04:51.301 --> 00:04:54.680
What do they call that when, Purgatory?

88
00:04:54.680 --> 00:04:59.434
[LAUGH] I think it's the wrong word.
>> I did not known that Microsoft also had

89
00:04:59.434 --> 00:05:00.710
a Purgatory setting.

90
00:05:00.710 --> 00:05:06.110
[LAUGH] I don't know if it's
a good document or bad document.

91
00:05:06.110 --> 00:05:09.125
They just kind of hang out there.
>> [LAUGH] I don't know why but

92
00:05:09.125 --> 00:05:14.433
that was the only thing that came to my
mind, that middle ground of where it's

93
00:05:14.433 --> 00:05:17.390
not really all the way Excel but it's not-

94
00:05:17.390 --> 00:05:18.240
>> Lite?
>> [LAUGH]

95
00:05:18.240 --> 00:05:18.999
>> [LAUGH] It's Excel Lite?

96
00:05:18.999 --> 00:05:21.187
[LAUGH]
>> Something like that, yeah.

97
00:05:21.187 --> 00:05:23.337
[LAUGH]
>> It is very similar.

98
00:05:23.337 --> 00:05:25.427
You see this setup not only in Excel but

99
00:05:25.427 --> 00:05:28.758
also whenever I'm representing
some kind of tabular data,

100
00:05:28.758 --> 00:05:33.480
whether I have categories, I have rows and
columns, and there's something there.

101
00:05:33.480 --> 00:05:37.512
So a lot of the utilities, very basic
utilities, if you can represent it as

102
00:05:37.512 --> 00:05:40.648
a table, then you have some of
the utilities that allow for

103
00:05:40.648 --> 00:05:41.822
charting as well.
>> And

104
00:05:41.822 --> 00:05:44.190
I like that you said tabular
data because that's what it is.

105
00:05:45.210 --> 00:05:49.450
Right here our series,
they're going to be in columns and

106
00:05:49.450 --> 00:05:53.150
the categories are going to be in a row.

107
00:05:53.150 --> 00:05:56.440
So you have to have that matrix,
if you wanna say.

108
00:05:56.440 --> 00:06:02.030
And how they get that chart information,
they are using Excel.

109
00:06:02.030 --> 00:06:04.165
But again, not the full version of Excel.

110
00:06:04.165 --> 00:06:06.735
And we're just gonna skip over
that whole Purgatory thing.

111
00:06:06.735 --> 00:06:09.688
I don't know.
>> I'm not gonna skip it, I'm gonna relish

112
00:06:09.688 --> 00:06:13.084
it for the rest of the day.
>> [LAUGH] We're just in this in between

113
00:06:13.084 --> 00:06:14.505
world, yeah, exactly.

114
00:06:14.505 --> 00:06:16.053
Okay, moving on.

115
00:06:16.053 --> 00:06:21.761
So we're gonna move on to some elements
that you can within your chart.

116
00:06:21.761 --> 00:06:25.875
And we recognize the data series and
the category axis but

117
00:06:25.875 --> 00:06:30.671
these little lines in here,
these are grid lines, the plot area,

118
00:06:30.671 --> 00:06:34.900
where it's actually plotting
out this information.

119
00:06:34.900 --> 00:06:36.600
Where's the chart area?

120
00:06:36.600 --> 00:06:42.040
These are the titles of each one of
the axes, this is the chart title.

121
00:06:42.040 --> 00:06:45.050
All of these different things
are parts that you can

122
00:06:45.050 --> 00:06:47.430
add as elements into your chart.

123
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:51.308
Your data labels, these little numbers
that are on top of your columns or

124
00:06:51.308 --> 00:06:53.801
your series,
you could go ahead and add that.

125
00:06:53.801 --> 00:06:59.889
These are all, again, Chart elements
that you can control whether or

126
00:06:59.889 --> 00:07:02.080
not you see them or not see them.

127
00:07:02.080 --> 00:07:03.436
This is another one that I like.

128
00:07:03.436 --> 00:07:06.690
I just put it on a separate slide
just because it's kinda bigger,

129
00:07:06.690 --> 00:07:08.500
something known as a data table.

130
00:07:08.500 --> 00:07:11.390
This could be good for things like,
all right, we're comparing.

131
00:07:11.390 --> 00:07:16.140
I can see definite Bishop likes to sleep
more than Fuego, but these numbers down

132
00:07:16.140 --> 00:07:21.670
here, you see how it's like 12.4526,
or 62, sorry I flipped those.

133
00:07:22.900 --> 00:07:26.570
You might not want that as data
labels on top of the columns but

134
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:30.160
you really want it to show the real value.

135
00:07:30.160 --> 00:07:33.776
So maybe having that data table can help

136
00:07:33.776 --> 00:07:38.170
show the numbers again
in that tabular format.

137
00:07:38.170 --> 00:07:41.570
Now what am I comparing on my category?

138
00:07:41.570 --> 00:07:44.420
This is where it's really
the same information,

139
00:07:44.420 --> 00:07:48.550
it's just flipped into
a different way of comparing it.

140
00:07:48.550 --> 00:07:53.020
Now you can see all
the activities of Fargo and

141
00:07:53.020 --> 00:07:55.960
all the activities of Bishop and
then the legend change.

142
00:07:55.960 --> 00:08:00.000
Basically we took the rows and
columns and turned them upside down.

143
00:08:00.000 --> 00:08:04.375
So this is how we want to compare and
show the information,

144
00:08:04.375 --> 00:08:07.123
mm-hm.
>> Now Vaughn, how you represent

145
00:08:07.123 --> 00:08:11.478
these whether it be with Fuego and
Bishop as the categorical axis or

146
00:08:11.478 --> 00:08:16.380
the respective activities as the
categorical axis instead of the legend,

147
00:08:16.380 --> 00:08:18.827
that's ultimately context based.

148
00:08:18.827 --> 00:08:20.300
What do I wanna compare?

149
00:08:20.300 --> 00:08:23.660
Do I wanna look at the relative
frequency of activities for Fuego so

150
00:08:23.660 --> 00:08:25.701
I can make a determination about Fuego?

151
00:08:25.701 --> 00:08:27.187
I'm gonna be honest with you but

152
00:08:27.187 --> 00:08:30.900
I'm having a hard time not laughing
when I say Fuego out loud.

153
00:08:30.900 --> 00:08:34.133
Let's switch to Bishop, or
I wanted to see Bishop as a whole but

154
00:08:34.133 --> 00:08:37.193
then I also have the ability
to compare the respective two.

155
00:08:37.193 --> 00:08:42.837
If I were to compare Bishop to Fuego,
Bishop sleeps a lot more than Fuego but

156
00:08:42.837 --> 00:08:48.110
in general he still does a lot of
playing as just considering Bishop.

157
00:08:48.110 --> 00:08:53.370
So, this is where charting gets fun for
me because how you make these decisions

158
00:08:53.370 --> 00:08:56.520
is very much contextual on what
you're trying to present or

159
00:08:56.520 --> 00:09:00.054
what determinations you're trying to make.
>> You made that sound so smart.

160
00:09:00.054 --> 00:09:01.343
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

161
00:09:01.343 --> 00:09:03.870
>> Yeah, exactly.

162
00:09:03.870 --> 00:09:04.990
What is your audience?

163
00:09:04.990 --> 00:09:07.140
What are you trying to communicate?

164
00:09:07.140 --> 00:09:07.692
That's huge.

165
00:09:07.692 --> 00:09:09.680
And a lot of times I have people say,

166
00:09:09.680 --> 00:09:13.920
I know what I want the chart to say
I just don't know how to get it.

167
00:09:13.920 --> 00:09:20.010
And that's where learning, one, just the
terminology and what it actually means and

168
00:09:20.010 --> 00:09:24.880
then how to get the numbers in the right
place and how to format it, and

169
00:09:24.880 --> 00:09:28.100
this, between this type of chart and
this, it's just one little button.

170
00:09:28.100 --> 00:09:30.422
You just click and say, flip.

171
00:09:30.422 --> 00:09:33.890
But if know what that really meant,
then it wouldn't be that easy.

172
00:09:33.890 --> 00:09:35.231
So that's why you're here.

173
00:09:35.231 --> 00:09:37.030
All right, let's keep on moving down here.

174
00:09:37.030 --> 00:09:39.190
So there's different types of charts.

175
00:09:39.190 --> 00:09:41.741
Now, this is a line graph.

176
00:09:41.741 --> 00:09:44.620
Graph, charts, I feel like
they're kind of interchangeable.

177
00:09:44.620 --> 00:09:46.060
I would call this a line graph.

178
00:09:46.060 --> 00:09:47.738
I wouldn't call it a line chart.

179
00:09:47.738 --> 00:09:48.620
I don't know why.

180
00:09:48.620 --> 00:09:52.532
Maybe it's just my own word but-
>> I'm gonna be honest,

181
00:09:52.532 --> 00:09:57.990
I don't call any of the ones in the chart
selection, charts, except for pie chart.

182
00:09:59.200 --> 00:10:02.800
Most of the rest of them to me,
just because of my background, are graphs.

183
00:10:02.800 --> 00:10:03.732
>> Yeah.

184
00:10:03.732 --> 00:10:04.351
>> Is a bar graph.

185
00:10:04.351 --> 00:10:06.040
This is a line graph.

186
00:10:06.040 --> 00:10:07.083
That's a pie chart.

187
00:10:07.083 --> 00:10:09.554
Yeah, it's really a pie graph.

188
00:10:09.554 --> 00:10:13.107
So to some extent there
are interchangeable, and that based on

189
00:10:13.107 --> 00:10:16.370
background and what you know them as.
>> And I think that's why I'm like,

190
00:10:16.370 --> 00:10:17.310
this is a line graph.

191
00:10:18.443 --> 00:10:20.550
I'm in the same boat with you.

192
00:10:20.550 --> 00:10:24.350
And talking about that pie chart,
there's one right there, so yep.

193
00:10:24.350 --> 00:10:27.927
And this is, like you were saying,
taking Fuego as a whole,

194
00:10:27.927 --> 00:10:30.746
and he's a big whole,
he's a big massive cat.

195
00:10:30.746 --> 00:10:34.820
But you could see that's probably why
he likes to sleep a lot right there.

196
00:10:34.820 --> 00:10:36.670
So this is just saying this is one part.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne show how to add and modify charts in Word 2016 for Mac. Vonne shows how to insert chart data for series and categories and how to modify existing chart data. They also identify the different areas of the chart and how to properly select elements to modify or format. They conclude with changing chart types and adding chart elements individually or with predefined layouts from the Quick Chart options.
episodes.title: Charts: Create and Layout

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin continue with charts in Word 2016. In this episode, they focus on formatting chart elements individually with fills and outlines as well as with styles. They also show how to format specific options of chart elements from the format pane. They then explore how a chart behaves as a graphical element in a Word document with positioning and wrap text.
episodes.title: Charts: Design and Format

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Daniel explore using text as graphical elements.  Vonne shows how to insert, format, and modify a text box.  She also shows how to create multiple linked text boxes to flow text from one text box to another. They also show how to insert WordArt as an individual element and how to create hyperlinks in a Word document to external webpages and files as well as internal within a document to headings and bookmarks.
episodes.title: Graphical Text Objects

particular area of the document,

Using headings is a really easy

00:29:25.860 --> 00:29:29.000

00:29:33.134 --> 00:29:35.863

If you make a bookmark first,

00:29:45.320 --> 00:29:50.570

553
00:29:50.570 --> 00:29:56.400
That once I mark this area as a bookmark,

I've used it a few times.
>> Well, Vonne, it was a fun and

It's a lot of fun, we played around

Because you can put those links in there,

569

So you can have fun with these things in

00:31:04.400 --> 00:31:04.960

579
00:31:04.960 --> 00:31:06.225

00:31:06.225 --> 00:31:11.435

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore the use of templates. They explain the commonly misused and misunderstood concept of a template and how to correctly use a template in Word.  They create documents from the built-in templates from Microsoft as well as creating a custom template from an existing document. They identify the default location of templates within the operating system and the importance of the normal template in Word.
episodes.title: Templates

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how to create and edit macros. They explain how macros can be helpful in automating repeatable steps, but also emphasize the potential security risk macros can pose if executed from an unknown source.
episodes.title: Macros
